div1.p: Kean is critical of the book written by Marie D. Gorgas because of its scientific and historical inaccuracies. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Burton Jesse Hendrick, March 9, 1925
div1.opener:
4
Reed & Gorgas II
Keep
March 9, 1925.
PERSONAL
Mr. Burton J. Hendrick,
Doubleday Page & Company,
Garden City, New York.
My dear Mr. Hendrick:
div1.p:
I am sending you today a copy of The Military
Surgeon for March in which I have printed as an editorial
a review of “William Crawford Gorgas; His Life and Work”
by Mrs. Gorgas and yourself.

I have a feeling that my review might have been
less sharply critical and the book would have been cer-
tainly more valuable if the authors had been a little more
receptive towards my desire last spring to correct the
historical inaccuracies. These are matters which from
the point of view of the story teller are of little moment
but from the scientific and historical standpoint they are
matters of great importance. I had the review read by
General Black with regard to the cleaning up of Havana and
by Dr. L. O. Howard with regard to Reed's attitude towards
the warfare on mosquitoes. Each has assured me that the
criticism were absolutely just and mildly stated.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, J. R. KEAN Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired,
Editor.
JRK/W
